name: Taj Mahal
facts: Commissioned by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of Mumtaz Mahal.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1983).
White marble reflects different hues at sunrise, daylight, and moonlight.
Fluted dome and four minarets exemplify Mughal symmetry.

name: Charminar
facts: Built by Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah; name means 'four minarets'.
Each minaret rises ~48m with balconies at multiple levels.
Laad Bazaar nearby is famed for lacquer bangles.

name: Konark Sun Temple
facts: Shaped like a colossal stone chariot dedicated to Surya.
24 carved wheels function as sundials.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1984).

name: Qutub Minar
facts: At ~73m, it’s one of the tallest brick minarets.
Started by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, completed by Iltutmish.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1993).

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
facts: Built by Raja Raja Chola I; towering vimana ~66m.
Granite Dravidian marvel; part of 'Great Living Chola Temples'.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1987, extended 2004).

name: Group of Monuments at Hampi
facts: Capital of the Vijayanagara Empire; ruins span temples, bazaars, and pavilions.
Virupaksha Temple and the iconic Stone Chariot are highlights.
UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Sanchi Stupa
facts: Commissioned under Emperor Ashoka; one of the oldest stone structures in India.
Noted for elaborately carved toranas (gateways).
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1989).

name: Ajanta Caves
facts: Buddhist rock-cut monasteries and prayer halls.
Renowned murals depict Jataka tales and Buddhist themes.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1983).

name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
facts: Famous for vividly painted gopurams and intricate sculptures.
Twin sanctums for Meenakshi (Parvati) and Sundareshwarar (Shiva).
The 'Hall of Thousand Pillars' showcases exquisite craftsmanship.

name: Khajuraho Group of Monuments
facts: Nagara-style temples famed for dynamic sculptures and motifs.
Around 20+ temples survive from an original ~85.
UNESCO World Heritage Site (1986).
